In the lower valley of the Mississippi these tumuli observe
a regular form, with very few exceptions. This form is almost uniformly a regular parallelogram at the base, rising in
in a pyramidal form to the surface or terrace, which is generally fiat and level. They are mostly oblong, being about

In shape these vary materially from those so common

mostly round, of a conical shape, and often much higher than

especially south of Tennessee, is sufficient to indicate a different race of men as the builders of each. The difference
in the form is too remarkable to have been the result of any

surrounding them is much more common in the north than
in the southern portion of this valley: in the south embankments about the mounds are uncommon ; while in the north
these embankments even occur where there is no mound.
The pyramidal square mound occurs in considerable numbers in the fertile alluvial bottoms as far east as Pearl river,
and probably to East Florida.
